ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: As a non-STEM person, I learned a ton about reproductive biology and the process of evolutionary adaptations. I have never been more of an expert on childbirth! This course also embeds in every student who takes it a deep gratitude for being alive - I would say that's a skill I learned through this course.

I expanded my knowledge on female reproductive ecology, as well as the cultural context surrounding it in both WEIRD and indigenous populations. I learned how to fact-check information from popular scientific articles and how to present scientific concepts to a lay audience.
Learned about the science and social elements of female bodies' reproductive lives.
I learned so much about the anatomical processes, evolutionary background, and cultural concepts that go along with the female reproductive system.

I gained a greater and more holistic understanding of female biological processes and anatomy. I also gained the ability to think critically about the scientific literature and media I consume and now know how to identify certain red flags an article may have that decreases its credibility.
I gained knowledge about the biology of female bodies and developed an understanding of the broader sociocultural dynamics that shape scientific knowledge.
I know so much more about female reproductive biology and how to approach biological from an anthropological lens

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Valeggia is an engaging lecturer, passionate scholar, and a great person, period. I did love the weekly discussion boards, but they allow for everyone to provide input on the material even if they are reluctant to share in class. In summary, the course itself is strong, the smaller assignments however can be tedious.

The strengths of this course are that you can really learn at your own speed. The assignment deadlines are very flexible (with the exception of the final project deadline of course), which creates a much less stressful learning environment compared to other Yale courses. You can also tell that Prof. Valeggia, as well as her TA Sakura are very invested in their students' academic and personal development. Moreover, Prof. Valeggia has done extensive research with the Qom people in Argentina, and it is a pleasure to see her passion for the research that she has conducted with indigenous populations. You can tell that Prof. Valeggia has great expertise in her field, and yet she is humble and eager to learn from her students, as well. The course also encourages students to really explore their interests and use their talents to the fullest.

A slight weakness of the course was that weekly assignments were too short (usually 350-400 words) to express any nuanced opinion. I do think that learning to concentrate information is important, but the short word limit encourages regurgitation of talking points and lack of reflection. This ties into another weakness of this course: other than the really cool perspectives on cultural practices and attitudes of the Qom people, the opinions presented are often reduced to typical US narratives of progressivism are presented as "truth," while everything else should be "unlearned." I am not against teaching typical US-American progressive ideas, but I do think that they should be accompanied with more diverse perspectives. I am also all for progress, but I believe that progress can look different for different people. Having a more "conservative" perspective-- or simply one that does not fit into any clear ideological framework in the US context-- was met with derision and hostility in class discussions (exclusively by peers though, the professor was very respectful of everyone!). I think the class could be improved by providing more diverse perspectives and by focusing slightly more on evolutionary biology, rather than 2020s US-focused ideological discussions. All in all, I had a great experience, though! I want to underline that I was still able to express my own opinions and that the professor herself was very respectful of everyone's perspective.

I think the section at the beginning of the course about transgenderism was actually the least interesting / relevant part of the course. Theres so much to discuss and I dont think its worth the opportunity cost.
Really strong class that covered interesting and nuanced topics. A great mix of scientific and anthropological content that appealed to students with a variety of interests. Manageable workload.

Strengths: Claudia is an absolute joy of a professor. She encourages students to forget the grade and just try to learn But she does not just say that. It truly holds with everything she does. The "leminar" formatting of the class is perfect, so I never feel like I'm being just talked to or just made to figure things out on my own. The material is interesting and essential for everyone to learn.

Weaknesses: None.

I appreciated how our classes were split into lectures and small group conversational seminars each week. That helped me both gain knowledge and understanding of that week's content, digest it, and be able to have a conversation about it later in the week. I believe this is the ideal classroom learning environment. I think towards the end of the semester we focused more on lectures, as there was more content to cover, and we lessened the number of small group conversations. If that can be avoided, I think that would improve and invite more student engagement during the second half of the semester.

Strengths: the professor and TF are wonderful,  the lecture/seminar structure is valuable, and the course does a great job of making everyone reflect on the material and carry those reflections forward in their own lives. 
Weaknesses: the discussions often felt one-sided and the class could benefit from more intellectual diversity. The group activities sometimes felt forced and and seemed to unintentionally trivialize the topics at hand. The interactive style of the class isnt always an effective method of learning.
Everything is strong, no weaknesses

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: absolutely - I wish every student at Yale could take this class
Absolutely!

I would recommend this course if you are interested in female physiology, as well as the cultural contexts in which different people around the world conceptualize female bodily processes, such as menarche, menstruation, pregnancy, lactation and menopause. I would not recommend this course if you are only interested in female physiology, as the class quite heavily focuses on culture and societal issues.
Absolutely. It covers information that anyone  man or woman  should know about. The female body and the intricacies of child bearing are relevant to all of us!

I would- you learn really important things and step outside your comfort zone, which is really positive. The professor and TA are absolutely amazing and have really interesting backgrounds, so I highly recommend a class with them.

I recommend this course to everyone with every fiber of my being. This class was more than a much needed revisit to what I had learned in Sex Ed class in high school. We challenged long-held beliefs at a high conceptual level, were encouraged to be curious and ask questions, and had a very fun time learning. I felt extremely supported as a learner, and felt that the classroom was a safe place to learn so many things that everyone should know.
YES! BEST CLASS EVER if you're a woman or ever plan to live with, be friends with, or commune with a woman. I have a deeper appreciation and understanding of my health and my habits.

I would recommend this course to anyone. Every person needs an accurate and true understanding of female reproductive biology, which this class offers. During this class, so many societally-constructed myths were broken down in my mind and I feel a deeper appreciation for the sanctity of life and the female body.
Yes, its a good science credit. The material is very interesting and the professor and TF are great.
YES if you can get into this class, take it. I loved not only the curriculum, but my classmates and the learning community we created. Professor Valeggia and TA Sakura are both AMAZING!
